posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
We have been having an issue where sometimes when we startup our robot the one of the swerve modules is out of rotation by 45 or 90 degrees (visual guess). A simple code restart often fixes this issue. The issue is not related to any other subsystems as the issue occurred before we had those integrated.

Here is our code: GitHub - HoyaRobotics/2023ChargedUp

link_counts.title: Swerve module not zeroing rarely & randomly, but still a problem

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked: Does the issue affect a random module, or only a specific one?

Sounds a lot like this issue: After restarting the Robot We need to re align the wheels at the start · Issue #8 · Team364/BaseFalconSwerve · GitHub

I’m not familiar with the details but appears like there’s some sort of race condition between inverting a motor and zeroing its sensor.

link_counts.title: After restarting the Robot We need to re align the wheels at the start · Issue #8 · Team364/BaseFalconSwerve · GitHub

posts.name: ErikSLee
posts.cooked: Have you tried putting in a slight delay before you call resetToAbsolute() in your configureAngleMotor? That seemed to work for us.

Joshua J:

Does the issue affect a random module, or only a specific one?

Our form of the issue typically affects a random module, with one module specifically being off more than others, module 0.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
Not sure but I think the issue was that with CAN Coders and phoenix 5 the can coders I believe default boot to zero and not absolute. The code then runs BootToAbsolutePosition which changes it to absolute position. Sometimes it doesn’t change to absolute position in time before the falcons are reset to the position of the CAN Coders. This means a module will sometimes get a relative position from startup which is 0 which means going forwards will face whatever you started at plus your offset. This also explains why restarting code would solve the issue as the CAN Coders are already booted and now in absolute position. To solve this issue I added a delay before resetting each encoder so it has time to boot to absolute.

Phoenix Pro and now Phoenix 6 solve this since the CAN Coders now boot to absolute be default. Haven’t tried the new code much but our latest phoenix 6 code removed the delay and we have not the issue again.

posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked: I was having this same issue. Just found your answer, and definitely helped us. Thanks
